stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing and modeling the interior of a milk bar/saloon for the cowboy-themed level. Key activities included planning the layout, conceptualizing a 'secret room' mission, implementing a custom additive blending effect for window light, and discussing a major pivot in design philosophy for the game's later levels.

development_findings.summary: The saloon level will feature a secret room where patrons illegally drink 'chalky milk,' forming the basis for a discovery-based mission.
development_findings.quote: They're not satisfied with milk. They need something a little stronger, a little illegal. They're actually not going for milk, they want chalky milk.

development_findings.summary: A new mechanic is being introduced where Dry Bones in the cowboy level are immune to normal jumps and require a ground pound to defeat, with the in-game lore attributing this to their milk consumption.
development_findings.quote: The Dry Bones in them hills, they got real strong bones. They spent their whole life drinking milk, so your little jumps ain't gonna do much.

development_findings.summary: Kaze articulated his design philosophy of preserving character identity through weaknesses, contrasting it with games like Project M which he feels homogenizes characters by removing their flaws.
development_findings.quote: It's like they looked at me and were like this character has a flaw let's fix it... you can't just take every character and remove their weaknesses and expect the game to be fun.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively reworking a 'lame' water raft section in Course 2, Divine Dino Domain, to be a more engaging platforming section using 'fling vines'.

A significant design pivot is occurring for the game's final levels; Kaze is abandoning 'uninspired' ideas like a music or comic book level in favor of more surreal concepts derived from dreams, similar to his process for *Lost Impact*.
A new level concept, a moving space station where events unfold as the player progresses, has been decided on for one of the later courses.
development_findings.quote: The level is gonna be like a relatively small space station, like a space shuttle with just things happening to it as you go. I think that's a really cool fantasy play.

development_findings.summary: Kaze defines a key design goal as achieving 'placeness,' where a level feels like a cohesive, believable location that the player feels they are living inside of.
Kaze believes that since he is modifying Nintendo's IP without permission, he cannot ethically object to others modifying his own work.
development_findings.quote: If you complain about people using your hack for something you're just being a little bitch. That's my view on this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that the fundamental purpose of human existence is creation, and to not create is to not truly be alive.
context_findings.quote: What would be the point of an existence where you don't create? That's like the whole purpose of the human soul. And you're gonna go without it? Damn. Are you even alive anymore at that point?

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a philosophical stance that since ROM hacking is done without the original creator's consent, he has no moral ground to complain if someone modifies his own hack.
context_findings.quote: If you hack someone else's game without their consent you should also be fine with someone hacking your hack against your consent. That seems logical to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is a strong proponent of using AI like ChatGPT as a development tool for tasks like generating code snippets or refining dialogue, viewing it as a 'better Google'.
context_findings.quote: I feel like people that are saying it's useless are just coping maybe because they're useless.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep-seated dislike for established conventions like 12-tone music theory and popular color theory, which he views as arbitrary, 'invented' fiction rather than being deduced from first principles. He desires to work with raw frequencies in music.
context_findings.quote: I don't like music theory cuz why the fuck is it 12 notes... Why are we limiting music so much? Don't like it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals the game has an underlying 'slavery plot' that he now feels needs to be overhauled because it may be too dark for a Mario game.
context_findings.quote: The whole slavery plot is a little bit dark for a Mario game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses sudden concern over the legal liability of selling merchandise based on Nintendo's IP, questioning the assurances from his merch partner, Pixel Empire.
context_findings.quote: Maybe I am actually the one taking on the legal responsibilities here and just fucking myself over.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intends to keep the game within the original N64's 8MB limitation, considering it part of the 'spirit of the challenge'.

biobak.summary: Kaze initially planned to use a specific window technique developed by Biobak for the saloon level.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, we need to use your window technique here. Look at this. It's so perfect, dude.

biobak.summary: Kaze decided against using one of Biobak's combiner methods for the saloon floor because it wouldn't allow for the multi-textured effect he wanted.
biobak.quote: Unfortunately I can't use biomex combiner. It's not gonna work in this situation. Because I do want the multi textured floor.

biobak.summary: Biobak sent Kaze assets for the window decals during the stream, which Kaze said he would import shortly.

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's music and mentions the desert theme is a banger.
badub.quote: Everything Banduke makes a banger, true.

badub.summary: Kaze is considering creating and selling a physical cartridge of the RTYI OST, composed by Badub, if new audio decompression technology for the N64 proves viable.
Kaze affirms his intention to pay Badub for his work on the soundtrack if the physical release happens.
badub.quote: I'm definitely gonna pay Barduke for the OST if we do end up making that cartridge.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for the animations of the Dry Bones characters.
Zeina contributed ideas for merchandise, suggesting a sticker with the phrase 'I hate video games'.
zeina.quote: Zayna thought the I hate video game thing is good.

zeina.summary: Zeina was identified as the second-most frequent chatter in Kaze's Twitch stream recap, indicating a high level of engagement during streams.

key_stories.title: Dreaming of Better Levels
key_stories.summary: Feeling that his planned level themes were becoming generic, Kaze reflected on his past work and realized his best ideas came from dreams. He made a significant creative pivot to abandon his current plans and instead develop more surreal, dream-inspired levels for the end of the game.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt his planned themes for the game's later courses were uninspired compared to his previous, highly-regarded work on *Lost Impact*.
key_stories.process: While streaming, Kaze reflected on the creative success of *Lost Impact*. He identified that its most memorable level themes were sourced from his dreams. He decided this method produced more unique results and resolved to apply the same 'dream logic' to RTYI's remaining courses.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze abandoned his previous plans for a music level and comic book level, committing instead to a new, more creative direction. He solidified the idea of a dynamic space station level and will use dreams and 'cool shit' as the primary source of inspiration for the remaining levels.
key_stories.key_quote: I thought back to how I came up with the Lost Impact themes. And usually all the themes in Lost Impact were just things that literally came to me in a dream. That's probably why they feel so inspired to me. And I think we should use that approach for the level themes.

key_stories.title: The AI Cowboy
key_stories.summary: Tasked with writing lore--heavy cowboy dialogue, Kaze turned to ChatGPT after his own attempts felt lacking. The AI produced text he deemed 'perfect,' which he adopted for the game, showcasing a practical application of AI in his creative workflow.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to write authentic-sounding cowboy dialogue for an NPC to explain a new game mechanic (stronger Dry Bones).
key_stories.process: After struggling to come up with cowboy slang himself, and getting suggestions from his chat, Kaze decided to use an AI tool. He prompted ChatGPT to rewrite his placeholder sentence in a cowboy style, and then cherry-picked the best parts of the generated text.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze was highly satisfied with the ChatGPT-generated dialogue, calling it 'perfect' and immediately deciding to use it in the game. The incident reinforced his belief in AI as a valuable and efficient development tool.
key_stories.key_quote: I reckon I give you a friendly tip. Them dry bones up in them hills, they're tough as all leather. Spend their days guzzling milk, so wrecking your little hops ain't gonna make a dent.

key_stories.title: The Chalky Milk Speakeasy
key_stories.summary: To give the saloon level purpose, Kaze designed a mission around a secret speakeasy. Here, patrons illegally drink 'chalky milk,' a humorous stand-in for alcohol. This narrative hook drives player exploration and provides a memorable, funny encounter.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a compelling mission and identity for the saloon interior beyond just being a decorative space.
key_stories.process: Kaze developed the initial 'milk bar' idea into a parody of a speakeasy. He planned for the player to overhear clues about a secret room, find a hidden doorknob blended into the wall, and uncover a group of NPCs illegally drinking 'chalky milk,' leading to a comical confrontation.
key_stories.outcome: The 'chalky milk speakeasy' became the central concept for the saloon, providing a mission structure (find the secret room), environmental storytelling, and a humorous narrative payoff.
key_stories.key_quote: There's going to be a secret room where a bunch of bad guys sit around the table drinking chalky milk... And what are they going to say? We got caught chalky handed.
